column4: hey guys, how can i create a startup script in ubuntu that will actually export enviroment variables?
i created a script in the /etc/init.d directory
but doesnt affect anything
but when it comes to starting up it does nothing
you want to change environment variables for your user?
i installed java manually, then i wrote an .sh script to export the path to JAVA_HOME and add the bin folder to the PATH
ok, you want to change these things for only your user or for everyone?
for everyone
use /etc/environment ,  but why not use the packaged java and save yourself this trouble?
i am writting a guide for a package installation and i do not want it to be dependend on apt
thanks for your help :)
Does the /etc/enviroment take effect when you are in a shell and sudo -s ? it doesnt appear to be the case, not sure why
probably only when you log into the gui, though I'm not sure
if i edit the .bashrc and say PATH="/usr/local/java/bin:$PATH" would this add that path to the root path?
what do you mean by "root path"?
the path for the root account, so that when i sudo i will have /pathtosomewhere available
ah, maybe if you are changing /root/.bashrc, but sudo does some cleaning up on the PATH when you use it like "sudo command"
yeah was refering to /root/.bashrc, it seems that it still does not accept the path i set there
sudo tries to keep the environment secure, and in ubuntu I think the path is when it is compiled
in other words there is no way of changing that path?
you can rebuild the package
I can't really think of a good reason to do so though
sudo -i solves the problem actually
ah, so it ends up sourcing .bashrc then?
